newsitem.title: SPAIN: SOCCER-REAL GO TOP WITH WIN AT UNLUCKY ZARAGOZA.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-REAL GO TOP WITH WIN AT UNLUCKY ZARAGOZA.

text.p: Real Madrid clawed their way back to the top of the Spanish first division on Tuesday thanks to two goals from Croatian striker Davor Suker in a controversial 2-1 win at Zaragoza.
With 21 points from nine games, Real go one point ahead of arch-rivals Barcelona, who play at Sevilla on Wednesday.
The result further endangers the position of Zaragoza coach Victor Fernandez, who just 16 months ago took his side to the European Cup Winners' Cup.
The game turned on a penalty decision 10 minutes from time when Real striker Predrag Mijatovic fell in the Zaragoza area after a challenge from Xavier Aguado.

The referee, who sent off Zaragoza's Vladislav Radimov moments later, incensed home fans still smarting from a hotly-disputed penalty decision which they believe cost them the game against Barcelona earlier this season.
Real had started strongly, and went ahead just after the quarter-hour when Suker knocked home a rebound from a shot by Dutch midfielder Clarence Seedorf.

But Zaragoza struck back, only to see Real's Bodo Illgner deflect a shot from Francisco Higuera onto the post after 37 minutes, while Gustavo Poyet beat the German 'keeper with a header that bounced off the bar on the stroke of halftime.
Poyet knocked in a cross from Higuera to grab a well-deserved equaliser just after the break, and for a time it looked as if Zaragoza would take control.
But then the referee ordered the penalty for the challenge on Mijatovic, who has been frequently accused of taking dives in the area this season.
Real had no problems hanging on to the lead after the decision to send off Radimov, in a curious incident in which the Russian appeared to kick the ball at the referee.
